headline: The Moral Challenge of Trumpism
abstract: Trumpism represents an alternative value system. The people I regard as upright and admirable MAGA regards as morally disgraceful.
lead_paragraph: I admire Mitt Romney. He is, by all accounts, an outstanding husband and father. He built a successful investment firm by supporting successful young businesses like Staples. He served the public as head of the 2002 Winter Olympics and as a governor. As a senator, he had the courage to vote to convict Donald Trump twice, in the two separate impeachment trials, when few other Republicans did.
snippet: Trumpism represents an alternative value system. The people I regard as upright and admirable MAGA regards as morally disgraceful.

headline: Canada Accuses Google of Creating an Ad Tech Monopoly
abstract: The case largely echoes an antitrust action in the United States and seeks to force Google to sell off sections of its online ad business.
lead_paragraph: Canada’s competition authority on Thursday accused Google of abusing its tools for buying and selling online advertising to create a monopoly, and filed a complaint seeking to force the company to sell two of its main advertising technology services.
snippet: The case largely echoes an antitrust action in the United States and seeks to force Google to sell off sections of its online ad business.

headline: Why Mexico Is Eliminating Independent Watchdog Agencies
abstract: A vote in the country’s Senate has cleared the way to abolish seven independent organizations that provided oversight on issues such as public information and price fixing.
lead_paragraph: Mexico’s Senate on Thursday night passed a sweeping proposal to dissolve several government-financed yet independent watchdog organizations, a move the president and her supporters said would help reduce corruption and waste. Critics have called it a step backward for transparency and regulation.
snippet: A vote in the country’s Senate has cleared the way to abolish seven independent organizations that provided oversight on issues such as public information and price fixing.

headline: Art Collector Who Bought a $6 Million Banana Offers to Buy 100,000 More
abstract: The vendor who sold the banana received only a quarter for the fruit. The buyer of the conceptual work has offered his stand a bigger payday, but logistical problems may be in the way.
lead_paragraph: A week after a Chinese cryptocurrency entrepreneur bought an artwork composed of a fresh banana stuck to a wall with duct tape for $6.2 million at auction, the man, Justin Sun, announced a grand gesture on X. He said he planned on purchasing 100,000 bananas — or $25,000 worth of the produce — from the Manhattan stand where the original fruit was sold for 25 cents.
snippet: The vendor who sold the banana received only a quarter for the fruit. The buyer of the conceptual work has offered his stand a bigger payday, but logistical problems may be in the way.

headline: Down for a Ski Trip
abstract: Willa Angel Chen Miller makes her New York Times Crossword debut, in a collaboration with Matthew Stock.
lead_paragraph: Jump to: Tricky Clues
snippet: Willa Angel Chen Miller makes her New York Times Crossword debut, in a collaboration with Matthew Stock.

headline: This Beloved Ginger Ale Is Made With a Dozen Ingredients
abstract: Plus: a California hot spring retreat, an exhibition of Dorothea Rockburne’s artwork and more recommendations from T Magazine.
lead_paragraph: The Danish brand Vipp was founded in 1939 with a single design: a waste bin. In the decades since, its product line has expanded to include a full furniture range, lighting and home accessories. In 2014, Vipp opened its first guesthouse, a contemporary prefab cabin near Lake Immeln, in southern Sweden. It now runs nine vacation rentals in Europe and, as of today, is taking reservations for its first in North America, a five-bedroom home in Todos Santos on the Pacific Coast of Mexico’s Baja California peninsula. Sofie Christensen Egelund, the third generation co-owner of Vipp, was introduced to the region by the Mexico City-based architect Pablo Pérez Palacios, who’s behind the property’s design. The 3,800-square-foot home has a rooftop pool and open interiors that highlight natural materials: The walls are made of rammed earth, while window shutters are woven from branches of the local Palo de Arco tree. Furnishings include some of Vipp’s own pieces as well as the brand’s signature kitchen, a modular system with minimalist hardware. Pérez Palacios sees the final space as “an ongoing dialogue between Mexican and Danish design sensibilities.” From $2,500 a night, vipp.com.
snippet: Plus: a California hot spring retreat, an exhibition of Dorothea Rockburne’s artwork and more recommendations from T Magazine.

headline: Quote of the Day: Georgia Winemakers, Long Tied to Russia, Drift Toward West
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Friday, November 29, 2024.
lead_paragraph: “We are not simply selling wine, we are selling our culture.”
snippet: Quotation of the Day for Friday, November 29, 2024.

headline: Four Decades Later, a Yearbook Prediction Comes to Fruition
abstract: Andrew Gottlieb had a crush on his good friend Steuart Osha. When they reconnected years later, things finally turned romantic.
lead_paragraph: In 1984, Andrew Gottlieb penned a note so long that it covered two pages of Elizabeth Alexandra Steuart Osha’s high school yearbook. In it, he matter-of-factly stated that they would one day get married. Four decades later his prediction came true.
snippet: Andrew Gottlieb had a crush on his good friend Steuart Osha. When they reconnected years later, things finally turned romantic.

headline: A Union That Was Meant to Be
abstract: The parents of Dr. Hilary Gallin and Joshua Brodie were trying to set them up for months. Little did they know, the couple had already connected.
lead_paragraph: When Dr. Hilary Gallin and Joshua Robert Brodie connected on Bumble in January 2023, they quickly realized their parents had been trying to set them up on a date for months.
snippet: The parents of Dr. Hilary Gallin and Joshua Brodie were trying to set them up for months. Little did they know, the couple had already connected.

headline: A Breakup Was Just the Beginning of Their Story
abstract: When Amaiya Davis and Matthew Wynter’s relationship ended abruptly, Ms. Davis blamed it on a cosmic shift, but she never lost hope. “I think part of me always knew we would get back together,” she said.
lead_paragraph: Amaiya Briani Davis thinks she was in the grips of the woolly astrological stage known as “Saturn return” in the spring of 2018. “It’s this period before you turn 30 when a lot of change happens,” she said.
snippet: When Amaiya Davis and Matthew Wynter’s relationship ended abruptly, Ms. Davis blamed it on a cosmic shift, but she never lost hope. “I think part of me always knew we would get back together,” she said.

headline: Black Friday Used to Be Fun. Now, Many Shoppers Would Rather Sleep In.
abstract: Lining up early outside stores and hunting for deals was once part of a gratifying Black Friday. It no longer feels that way.
lead_paragraph: For Max Frazier, shopping on Black Friday used to be one of his favorite annual traditions.
snippet: Lining up early outside stores and hunting for deals was once part of a gratifying Black Friday. It no longer feels that way.

headline: It All Started With an Unexpected Hug and a Selfie
abstract: Jeffrey Ballou and Rasheedah Thomas unintentionally memorialized what would become one of the most significant days of their lives.
lead_paragraph: One of Rasheedah Iman Thomas’s most treasured photos is an impromptu selfie she took with a stranger who was a fellow guest at a friend’s birthday party in May 2018.
snippet: Jeffrey Ballou and Rasheedah Thomas unintentionally memorialized what would become one of the most significant days of their lives.

headline: Killer Whales Hunt and Feast on the Largest Fish On Earth
abstract: Whale sharks are gentle, filter-feeding giants, but orcas in Mexican waters were documented attacking the animals and devouring their livers.
lead_paragraph: Off Baja California in Mexico, a killer whale named after an Aztec emperor is leading his pod on routine takedowns of the largest fish in the sea: whale sharks.
snippet: Whale sharks are gentle, filter-feeding giants, but orcas in Mexican waters were documented attacking the animals and devouring their livers.

headline: A Dublin Neighborhood at the Sharp End of Ireland’s Election Issues
abstract: In a northeast neighborhood of the capital city, deprivation and affluence exist side-by-side, and many voters feel frustrated by the status quo.
lead_paragraph: On the lamp posts in northeast Dublin, campaign posters are stacked one on top of the next, the faces of prominent politicians and newcomers competing for attention ahead of Ireland’s general election on Friday.
snippet: In a northeast neighborhood of the capital city, deprivation and affluence exist side-by-side, and many voters feel frustrated by the status quo.

headline: Friday Briefing
abstract: The cease-fire between Israel and Hezbollah.
lead_paragraph: After months of fighter jets and rockets in the skies and explosions erupting on the ground, quiet reigned over much of Lebanon and northern Israel yesterday.
snippet: The cease-fire between Israel and Hezbollah.

headline: Chinese Court Sentences Journalist to 7 Years in Prison for Espionage
abstract: Dong Yuyu, who has written articles critical of the Communist Party, was arrested in 2022 while having lunch with a Japanese diplomat.
lead_paragraph: A Chinese court sentenced a high-ranking editor and columnist for a major Communist Party newspaper to seven years in prison on espionage charges on Friday. His family said it was punishment for past writings that were critical of the government, as well as a warning to Chinese citizens against engaging with foreigners.
snippet: Dong Yuyu, who has written articles critical of the Communist Party, was arrested in 2022 while having lunch with a Japanese diplomat.

headline: Four Opinion Writers on ‘Wicked’: ‘Women Deserve Rage. We Have a Lot to Be Angry About.’
abstract: A big-budget holiday film with a strong antifascist message? “Wicked” is not what we expected.
lead_paragraph: Patrick Healy, the deputy Opinion editor, hosted an online conversation with the Times Opinion columnists Maureen Dowd, Tressie McMillan Cottom and Lydia Polgreen about the new movie “Wicked.”
snippet: A big-budget holiday film with a strong antifascist message? “Wicked” is not what we expected.

headline: My Traumatized Dog and I Had Trust Issues
abstract: We needed a steady presence in our lives. Enter Kevin.
lead_paragraph: One morning, leaving for work, I stepped outside the gate of my apartment building and heard a rustle of activity to my left. I turned to see a tiny dog trotting toward me on the sidewalk, looking nervously back at a knot of people who were following and calling out.
snippet: We needed a steady presence in our lives. Enter Kevin.

headline: How China Became the World’s Largest Car Exporter
abstract: Tariffs from the United States and other countries are unlikely to stop China’s auto export dominance.
lead_paragraph: Tariffs from the United States and other countries are unlikely to stop China’s auto export dominance.
snippet: Tariffs from the United States and other countries are unlikely to stop China’s auto export dominance.

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
abstract: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
lead_paragraph: Hi, busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. Enter the comments section to see hints, conversation, helpful tips and creative content from other solvers.
snippet: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.

headline: The Great Opera Tradition Died With Puccini
abstract: A century after his death, the composer of “La Bohème,” “Tosca” and “Madama Butterfly” still dominates the repertoire like no one since.
lead_paragraph: There’s a knock at the door.
snippet: A century after his death, the composer of “La Bohème,” “Tosca” and “Madama Butterfly” still dominates the repertoire like no one since.

headline: Will Hochul’s Political Concerns Put New York’s Climate Goals at Risk?
abstract: Gov. Kathy Hochul is contending with pressures from environmental advocates and President-elect Donald Trump as she charts a path forward.
lead_paragraph: In 2019, New York passed a sweeping law that promised to drastically reduce emissions and make New York an example for the nation.
snippet: Gov. Kathy Hochul is contending with pressures from environmental advocates and President-elect Donald Trump as she charts a path forward.

headline: Goodbye, Chain Drugstores. Hello, Golf Simulators.
abstract: New York’s retail landscape is changing. But it’s not cheese shops or butchers that are taking over those vacant neighborhood storefronts.
lead_paragraph: Over the past year or so, the commercial real estate industry has made it very easy for me to satisfy an urge I am not sure I will ever have. Within a six- or seven-minute walk from my apartment in Brooklyn, it is now possible to get to two indoor golf simulators — places where the purpose is to successfully whack a ball into a 10-ft screen that delivers digital replicas of famous golf courses and a soul-crushing lineup of metrics about the reach, speed and accuracy of any particular swing.
snippet: New York’s retail landscape is changing. But it’s not cheese shops or butchers that are taking over those vacant neighborhood storefronts.

headline: Can a Court’s ‘Last Resort’ Fix New York City’s Jails?
abstract: A federal judge is likely to employ a rarely used remedy to try to fix longstanding problems in the city’s jails. But it’s not foolproof.
lead_paragraph: Conditions in Alabama’s prison system had been so miserable, for so long, in 1976 that a federal judge took the unusual step of appointing an outside authority to fix them.
snippet: A federal judge is likely to employ a rarely used remedy to try to fix longstanding problems in the city’s jails. But it’s not foolproof.

headline: The Many Faces of NEETs
abstract: The acronym for young people “not in education, employment or training” has been all over the internet lately. But like Gen Z-ers themselves, the term can be misunderstood.
lead_paragraph: When they aren’t roasting millennials’ outfits or scrolling on TikTok, how are Gen Z-ers spending their time?
snippet: The acronym for young people “not in education, employment or training” has been all over the internet lately. But like Gen Z-ers themselves, the term can be misunderstood.

headline: Ukraine’s River of Anguish
abstract: Amphibious operations across the Dnipro River at Kherson illustrated the suffering and endurance of Ukrainian forces. A team of Times journalists observed the perilous movements.
lead_paragraph: Late at night, half a dozen Ukrainian infantrymen leaned over a map spread on wooden pallets inside a building. Within an hour they would embark on one of the most dangerous deployments of the war, a nighttime operation across the Dnipro River.
snippet: Amphibious operations across the Dnipro River at Kherson illustrated the suffering and endurance of Ukrainian forces. A team of Times journalists observed the perilous movements.

headline: U.S. Zoos Gave a Fortune to Protect Pandas. That’s Not How China Spent It.
abstract: A Times investigation found that zoos knew conservation money went toward apartment buildings and roads. But they wanted to keep displaying pandas, so nobody looked too closely.
lead_paragraph: For decades, American zoos have raised tens of millions of dollars from donors and sent the money to China for the right to host and display pandas. Under U.S. law, those funds were required to be spent protecting pandas in the wild.
snippet: A Times investigation found that zoos knew conservation money went toward apartment buildings and roads. But they wanted to keep displaying pandas, so nobody looked too closely.

headline: An Elegy for Crystal Cove A7, Our Family’s Piece of Paradise
abstract: A one-bedroom vacation condo on St. Thomas was heaven for a writer when she was growing up. But what did the place mean after her parents were gone?
lead_paragraph: The setting for some of my most treasured childhood memories is a one-bedroom condo that stood 75 feet from a white sand beach, overlooking the absurdly blue Caribbean. To my sister and me, it was heaven, with Murphy beds — the coolest gizmos ever — folding down at night and disappearing each day.
snippet: A one-bedroom vacation condo on St. Thomas was heaven for a writer when she was growing up. But what did the place mean after her parents were gone?

headline: Ms. Rachel’s Improbable Journey From Toddler Whisperer to Holiday Toy Story
abstract: Rachel Accurso might be this era’s Mister Rogers, if he had been on YouTube, TikTok and Instagram. Toy companies and publishers all want a piece of the action.
lead_paragraph: About a year and a half ago, Laura Henderson, a toy company executive and 38-year-old mother in Toronto, was at the tail end of maternity leave with her second child. She was bleary-eyed and overwhelmed, as mothers juggling an infant and toddler tend to be, when she started scrolling TikTok and stumbled upon the children’s personality known as Ms. Rachel.
snippet: Rachel Accurso might be this era’s Mister Rogers, if he had been on YouTube, TikTok and Instagram. Toy companies and publishers all want a piece of the action.

headline: An Apocalyptic Novel Throws Stones at the Glass House of ‘King Lear’
abstract: Julia Armfield’s “Private Rites” is a contemporary reimagining of the Shakespearean tragedy, set in a flooded London.
lead_paragraph: “Blow, winds, and crack your cheeks! Rage! Blow!/You cataracts and hurricanoes, spout/Till you have drench’d our steeples,” Shakespeare’s King Lear shouts into the storm after he is spurned by two of his three daughters. Taking his desperate cry as its inspiration, Julia Armfield’s captivating novel “Private Rites” imagines a present city resembling London where storms haven’t just drenched steeples; they’ve drowned entire churches. Amid incessant rain, “narrowing gaps between floodplains,” unstable electrical grids and homes “whose foundations are coming apart,” an architect named Stephen Carmichael is celebrated in lavish coffee-table books for his ingenious, cantilevered structures built in “hillside enclaves … where it is still possible to stroll or drive a car,” hovering above the poor and the rising water levels. Following his death, his three queer adult daughters are left to grapple with his legacy, his divisive will and his “easy cruelty.”
snippet: Julia Armfield’s “Private Rites” is a contemporary reimagining of the Shakespearean tragedy, set in a flooded London.

headline: How Online Shoppers Are Trying to Foil ‘Porch Pirates’
abstract: Some people race to grab their packages before thieves can nab them. Others move to buildings with dedicated mailrooms.
lead_paragraph: Good news: Your package has been delivered.
snippet: Some people race to grab their packages before thieves can nab them. Others move to buildings with dedicated mailrooms.

headline: The Price of Being Cool? A Quarter-Billion Dollars.
abstract: The WSA building, a 31-story New York office tower with mysterious financing, has become an improbable hub for artists, designers and influencers.
lead_paragraph: Deep in the canyons of New York’s financial district, there is an office tower that matches the cultural moment, for better and for worse. It might be the first “It” building.
snippet: The WSA building, a 31-story New York office tower with mysterious financing, has become an improbable hub for artists, designers and influencers.

headline: The Heirs of a Despised Draft Dodger Want His Wright Brothers Plane Back
abstract: The Franklin Institute has said a wealthy scion, long vilified for refusing to serve during World War I, gave them a treasured Wright-built plane. His family is challenging that account.
lead_paragraph: The Franklin Institute, a Philadelphia museum dedicated to the study of science, has long said one of its most impressive holdings — a plane built in 1911 by the Wright brothers — was a gift from a man named Grover C. Bergdoll.
snippet: The Franklin Institute has said a wealthy scion, long vilified for refusing to serve during World War I, gave them a treasured Wright-built plane. His family is challenging that account.

headline: Transcendent (and Occasionally Filthy) New Romance Novels
abstract: Our columnist on some recent favorites.
lead_paragraph: Category romances — those slim titles issued every month from themed imprints — are the high-end sports cars of the book world. Impractical luxuries, they’re designed for a single purpose: to go vroom very fast. They’re not always subtle, but when they succeed, they’re absolutely exhilarating.
snippet: Our columnist on some recent favorites.

headline: Margo Martindale Pours It On in ‘The Sticky’
abstract: The esteemed character actress has spent decades enlivening films and series in just a few scenes or episodes. In this new Amazon heist comedy, she is first on the call sheet.
lead_paragraph: Let’s say you need a woman who can slit someone’s throat, who can poison someone’s whiskey, who can smash her son’s fingers with a hammer, who can commit armed robbery with precision and glee. Perhaps you are responsible for “The Sticky,” a new Amazon heist comedy, premiering on Dec. 6, and you require an actress who can reliably crash most of a maple tree through the glass doors of a provincial office building.
snippet: The esteemed character actress has spent decades enlivening films and series in just a few scenes or episodes. In this new Amazon heist comedy, she is first on the call sheet.

headline: How the Bonne Maman Advent Calendar Became a Hot Commodity
abstract: More than a year of research and development plus word-of-mouth has kept the French jam company’s calendars in shopping carts.
lead_paragraph: Maybe it’s the inspired flavors like pear with cocoa nibs or pineapple and yuzu, the affordability ($45) or the cute little jars that can be repurposed to hold spices or jewelry. But out of the many covetable food-based Advent calendars, those from a 53-year-old jam company are the hottest commodity.
snippet: More than a year of research and development plus word-of-mouth has kept the French jam company’s calendars in shopping carts.

headline: Holiday Shopping Season Separates Winning Retailers From Losers
abstract: Consumers are seeking deals and being choosier about their spending in the crucial final weeks of the year, executives say.
lead_paragraph: Shoppers are heading into the Black Friday weekend unsure how wide to open their wallets, retailers say, with many still feeling the squeeze of inflation and also worried that tariffs could make things even more expensive if they wait too long to buy.
snippet: Consumers are seeking deals and being choosier about their spending in the crucial final weeks of the year, executives say.

headline: Kennedy’s Inheritance: How Addiction and Trauma Shaped a Turbulent Life
abstract: Donald Trump’s pick to be health secretary, Robert F. Kennedy Jr. has reached a pinnacle of power after a life of fame and addictions and a career intertwined with conspiracy theories.
lead_paragraph: In September 1983, Robert F. Kennedy Jr. fell ill on a flight to Rapid City, S.D. The pilot radioed ahead for medics. By dint of his famous name, Mr. Kennedy, then 29 and fresh out of law school, was taken to a V.I.P. room at the airport, where investigators found heroin in his luggage.
snippet: Donald Trump’s pick to be health secretary, Robert F. Kennedy Jr. has reached a pinnacle of power after a life of fame and addictions and a career intertwined with conspiracy theories.

headline: Trump May Find Things to Like About Biden’s ‘Horrible’ Foreign Policy
abstract: The world is braced for disruption from the president-elect, but he may find more common ground with President Biden than many assume.
lead_paragraph: President-elect Donald J. Trump comes to office with a view of America’s place in the world that is dramatically different from his predecessor’s.
snippet: The world is braced for disruption from the president-elect, but he may find more common ground with President Biden than many assume.

headline: Casting the Cabinet
abstract: The Trump cabinet is mostly complete — at least until the official nomination and confirmation process — and it is quite a picture.
lead_paragraph: People who are casually following the recent announcements from President-elect Donald J. Trump about how he intends to staff the upper ranks of the executive branch could be forgiven for thinking they were reading about a beauty contest, not political appointments. If, during his first administration, Mr. Trump boasted of his generals from “central casting,” now, it seems, he has applied the same principle to the whole shebang.
snippet: The Trump cabinet is mostly complete — at least until the official nomination and confirmation process — and it is quite a picture.

headline: When Zoos Pay for Endangered Species: Our Correspondent Explains the Risks
abstract: We tracked $86 million in U.S. money that was supposed to go toward panda conservation in China.
lead_paragraph: Pandas are a vulnerable species. American zoos are allowed to fly them in from China and display them to tourists on one condition: They have to prove to federal regulators that they are helping pandas in the wild.
snippet: We tracked $86 million in U.S. money that was supposed to go toward panda conservation in China.

headline: She Was Scratching Her Arms Raw. Would Anything Stop This Itch?
abstract: The attacks came out of nowhere and brought life to a miserable standstill. And she had the scars to prove it.
lead_paragraph: The 62-year-old woman shifted in her seat. The flight to Honolulu was full, the mood a little giddy. The unbroken ocean and sky filled the window. She and her daughter were four hours into the trip from Los Angeles to the wedding of a close family friend; it was going to be a great week. Then, she caught herself scratching lightly at a place on her forearm, just below the crease of her elbow. She lifted her arm to look at the spot. Nothing there. Immediately she was filled with dread.
snippet: The attacks came out of nowhere and brought life to a miserable standstill. And she had the scars to prove it.

headline: Death of Cyclist in Paris Lays Bare Divide in Mayor’s War Against Cars
abstract: Paul Varry was run over on a city street in what prosecutors suspect was a deliberate act of road rage, as bikers and drivers choose sides.
lead_paragraph: It sent a shock through Paris, a city striving to transform itself into one of the great cycling metropolises in the world: a bicycle rider, crushed under the wheels of an SUV in a bike lane just a few yards from La Madeleine, the landmark neoclassical church, in what prosecutors suspect was a deliberate act of road rage.
snippet: Paul Varry was run over on a city street in what prosecutors suspect was a deliberate act of road rage, as bikers and drivers choose sides.

headline: How to Visit Notre-Dame Cathedral in Paris
abstract: After a fire shuttered the beloved Gothic landmark for five years, visitor demand is expected to be high once the doors reopen Dec. 8. Here’s how to plan your visit and what to expect.
lead_paragraph: On Dec. 8, the doors of Notre-Dame Cathedral in Paris are scheduled to reopen to the public after a fire engulfed the beloved structure five years ago.
snippet: After a fire shuttered the beloved Gothic landmark for five years, visitor demand is expected to be high once the doors reopen Dec. 8. Here’s how to plan your visit and what to expect.

headline: Will the Markets Check Trump’s Power?
abstract: The president-elect cares about financial markets, our columnist says. That gives investors a restraint on his decisions, even if it’s a tenuous one.
lead_paragraph: The president-elect follows the markets closely. He bragged frequently about how well stocks performed in his first term in office, and said they had boomed this year in anticipation of his return to the White House.
snippet: The president-elect cares about financial markets, our columnist says. That gives investors a restraint on his decisions, even if it’s a tenuous one.

headline: The Churchill of Staten Island
abstract: On the 150th anniversary of Winston Churchill’s birth, Luke Boyd, a Churchill impersonator who lives on Staten Island, will get up at 11 a.m.: “When Sir Winston would have.”
lead_paragraph: Good morning. It’s Friday. We’ll find out how a Winston Churchill impersonator plans to spend Churchill’s 150th birthday. We’ll also meet the new head of New York City Transit, the division of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority that runs the subways and buses.
snippet: On the 150th anniversary of Winston Churchill’s birth, Luke Boyd, a Churchill impersonator who lives on Staten Island, will get up at 11 a.m.: “When Sir Winston would have.”

headline: $1.3 Million Homes in Paris
abstract: A one-bedroom with a showcase ceiling in Marais, a lofted three-bedroom apartment on Avenue Frochot, and a three-bedroom unit in the 10th Arrondissement.
lead_paragraph: This one-bedroom, two-bath apartment with thick wood beams crisscrossing the living room ceiling is on the top two floors of a 17th-century building in central Paris. Modern touches, including an elevator, a sleek black-and-white bathroom and a designer spiral staircase bring the unit into the modern era.
snippet: A one-bedroom with a showcase ceiling in Marais, a lofted three-bedroom apartment on Avenue Frochot, and a three-bedroom unit in the 10th Arrondissement.

headline: 6 New Movies Our Critics Are Talking About This Week
abstract: Whether you’re a casual moviegoer or an avid buff, our reviewers think these films are worth knowing about.
lead_paragraph: This adaptation of William S. Borough’s autobiographical novella directed by Luca Guadagnino follows William Lee (Daniel Craig), a louche, lonely soul who pines after a younger man.
snippet: Whether you’re a casual moviegoer or an avid buff, our reviewers think these films are worth knowing about.

headline: Almost Every Part of This Warming Winter Feast Can Be Made Ahead
abstract: Prepare David Tanis’s savory lamb stew and fancy-feeling crepes well before guests arrive, and actually enjoy the day of your dinner party.
lead_paragraph: I’ve always been a big fan of cooking today for tomorrow.
snippet: Prepare David Tanis’s savory lamb stew and fancy-feeling crepes well before guests arrive, and actually enjoy the day of your dinner party.

headline: Three Great Documentaries to Stream
abstract: Picks this month include two films about life under troubled governments and one about life under a demanding filmmaker.
lead_paragraph: The proliferation of documentaries on streaming services makes it difficult to choose what to watch. Each month, we’ll select three nonfiction films — classics, overlooked recent docs and more — that will reward your time.
snippet: Picks this month include two films about life under troubled governments and one about life under a demanding filmmaker.

headline: Artists, Then (as in the 17th Century) and Now
abstract: “The Light and the Dark” dramatizes the life of Artemisia Gentileschi, while “300 Paintings” was born during the fever dreams of Covid.
lead_paragraph: Quick! Which 17th-century female artist fought her way into the male-dominated art world, prevailed in a rape trial and alchemized her struggles into revolutionary art? If the name Artemisia Gentileschi doesn’t leap to one’s lips, Kate Hamill’s play “The Light and the Dark” at 59E59 Theaters offers a generous introduction.
snippet: “The Light and the Dark” dramatizes the life of Artemisia Gentileschi, while “300 Paintings” was born during the fever dreams of Covid.

headline: Nursing Home Industry Wants Trump to Rescind Staffing Mandate
abstract: A Biden administration rule that imposed minimum rules on nursing levels may not survive, even though many homes lack enough workers to maintain residents’ care.
lead_paragraph: Covid’s rampage through the country’s nursing homes killed more than 172,000 residents and spurred the biggest industry reform in decades: a mandate that homes employ a minimum number of nurses.
snippet: A Biden administration rule that imposed minimum rules on nursing levels may not survive, even though many homes lack enough workers to maintain residents’ care.

headline: Mark Duplass Reprises a Killer Role in ‘The Creep Tapes’
abstract: The murderer with the unnerving smile from the “Creep” movies is back, this time in a found-footage-style series on Shudder. Keep the camera rolling.
lead_paragraph: It has been almost 10 years since Mark Duplass put on a monstrous smile in “Creep,” a found-footage horror movie about a serial killer named Josef who lures videographers to his home and slaughters them mercilessly on camera.
snippet: The murderer with the unnerving smile from the “Creep” movies is back, this time in a found-footage-style series on Shudder. Keep the camera rolling.

headline: ‘Stick Season’ Gave This Vermont General Store Pop Music Fame. Now It Needs a Proprietor.
abstract: The hit singer Noah Kahan grew up frequenting Coburns’ General Store and has called it “the heart” of his hometown. His mother is helping lead an effort to save it.
lead_paragraph: The residents of Strafford, Vt., cannot imagine their town without Coburns’ General Store, a hub so quirky and cozy, so steeped in New England authenticity, it could be the setting for a novel — or the inspiration for a song.
snippet: The hit singer Noah Kahan grew up frequenting Coburns’ General Store and has called it “the heart” of his hometown. His mother is helping lead an effort to save it.

headline: Life After Death: America’s Cemeteries Are Rewilding
abstract: More burial sites are forgoing pristine lawns for drought resistant plants and wildflowers that help wildlife. Efforts picked up in the pandemic.
lead_paragraph: Across the country, where the dead lie, life is increasingly thriving.
snippet: More burial sites are forgoing pristine lawns for drought resistant plants and wildflowers that help wildlife. Efforts picked up in the pandemic.

headline: The New York Times News Quiz, Nov. 29, 2024
abstract: Did you follow the news this week? Take our quiz to see how well you stack up with other Times readers.
lead_paragraph: Did you follow the news this week? Take our quiz to see how well you stack up with other Times readers.
snippet: Did you follow the news this week? Take our quiz to see how well you stack up with other Times readers.

headline: Looking for Quality Indie Cinema? Try Ovid.
abstract: The streaming service is a great place for independent films off the beaten path.
lead_paragraph: Over the past several months, we’ve examined and recommended several streaming services for the discriminating movie lover — sites and apps for those whose tastes run toward titles a bit more esoteric than the likes of Netflix and Amazon Prime Video. Our latest entry spotlights a terrific subscription streamer for independent film fans.
snippet: The streaming service is a great place for independent films off the beaten path.

headline: We Asked for Your Offbeat Holiday Traditions. You Delivered.
abstract: Families with holiday rituals are more likely to gather. So here’s to “Ribsgiving,” stinky gifts and fried oysters for Christmas breakfast.
lead_paragraph: When I was growing up, we had a family tradition that I didn’t know was weird. For regular meals, we folded our paper napkins in half in a rectangular shape. But for holiday dinners, we folded them diagonally — which, for reasons that have never been made clear, my parents viewed as more formal.
snippet: Families with holiday rituals are more likely to gather. So here’s to “Ribsgiving,” stinky gifts and fried oysters for Christmas breakfast.

headline: After a Cease-Fire in Lebanon, Gaza and Iran’s Nuclear Ambitions Await Trump
abstract: A broader peace in the Middle East will be difficult to achieve, and Iran’s threat to Israel looms over any diplomatic effort.
lead_paragraph: Difficult as it was to achieve, the cease-fire in Lebanon was the easy part.
snippet: A broader peace in the Middle East will be difficult to achieve, and Iran’s threat to Israel looms over any diplomatic effort.

headline: Russia, Targeting Ukraine’s Grid, Moves to Cut Off Its Nuclear Plants
abstract: Moscow has increasingly hit critical substations linked to nuclear power plants in an effort to disconnect them. At the same time, Ukraine replaced the commander of its ground forces.
lead_paragraph: Russia hit critical electricity transmission facilities linked to nuclear power plants during its latest assault on Ukraine’s power grid on Thursday, the International Atomic Energy Agency reported. It was the third such attack in roughly as many months, heightening concerns among experts about the potential for a nuclear disaster.
snippet: Moscow has increasingly hit critical substations linked to nuclear power plants in an effort to disconnect them. At the same time, Ukraine replaced the commander of its ground forces.

headline: Israel Warns Residents on Both Sides of Lebanon Border to Stay Away
abstract: The cease-fire appeared to largely be holding, but it was unclear when hundreds of thousands of Lebanese and tens of thousands of Israelis could return to their homes near the border.
lead_paragraph: The Israeli military issued new warnings to residents on both sides of the Israel-Lebanon border on Friday, telling them not to return to their homes, as the fragile U.S.-brokered cease-fire between Israel and Hezbollah appeared to largely hold despite another Israeli strike in southern Lebanon.
snippet: The cease-fire appeared to largely be holding, but it was unclear when hundreds of thousands of Lebanese and tens of thousands of Israelis could return to their homes near the border.

headline: The Connections Companion No. 538
abstract: Scroll down for hints and conversation about the puzzle for Saturday, Nov. 30, 2024.
lead_paragraph: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.
snippet: Scroll down for hints and conversation about the puzzle for Saturday, Nov. 30, 2024.

headline: Wordle Review No. 1,260
abstract: Scroll down for hints and conversation about the puzzle for Nov. 30, 2024.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.
snippet: Scroll down for hints and conversation about the puzzle for Nov. 30, 2024.

headline: Thanksgiving Leftovers
abstract: Make the most of your leftover food.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. How’d it go yesterday? Was the turkey moist? The gravy smooth? You enjoy the side dishes, the dinner rolls? Were the pies abundant? Did Cousin Amy keep her cool?
snippet: Make the most of your leftover food.

headline: Supporting Local News, and Doctors Taking a Risk
abstract: With Trump’s return, both journalists and abortion pill providers need help.
lead_paragraph: This article is part of Times Opinion’s Giving Guide 2024. Read more in a note from Times Opinion’s editor, Kathleen Kingsbury.
snippet: With Trump’s return, both journalists and abortion pill providers need help.

headline: Alzheimer’s Can Be a World of Endless Second Chances
abstract: When Dad first started forgetting things, I thought I’d lost him. I didn’t imagine I’d have more of him than I did before.
lead_paragraph: Every week, I visit my father, who has Alzheimer’s and lives alone. When I tell people this they say, “Is that safe?”
snippet: When Dad first started forgetting things, I thought I’d lost him. I didn’t imagine I’d have more of him than I did before.

headline: How Not to Fall Into Despair
abstract: When in chaos, try tragic optimism, wise hope and wise action.
lead_paragraph: When we find ourselves in the thick of disorder, uncertainty or loss, resilience can seem impossible, even trite, to hope for.
snippet: When in chaos, try tragic optimism, wise hope and wise action.

headline: Republican and Democratic Former Senate Counsels Agree: F.B.I. Checks on Trump Nominees Are a Must
abstract: With fewer and fewer checks on presidential power, we need rigorous congressional consideration of the incoming president’s team.
lead_paragraph: For several years, we were the Republican and Democratic counsels who reviewed presidential nominees’ background checks for the Senate Judiciary Committee. We know how the confirmation process is supposed to work and how important F.B.I. vetting is to that process. That’s why we’re appalled by reports that the new Republican-led Senate and the incoming Trump administration may dispense with it.
snippet: With fewer and fewer checks on presidential power, we need rigorous congressional consideration of the incoming president’s team.

headline: A Bird Flu Pandemic Would Be One of the Most Foreseeable Catastrophes in History
abstract: It’s not too late for President Biden to give the U.S. a life-changing gift.
lead_paragraph: Almost five years after Covid blew into our lives, the main thing standing between us and the next global pandemic is luck. And with the advent of flu season, that luck may well be running out.
snippet: It’s not too late for President Biden to give the U.S. a life-changing gift.

headline: Hard Fork’s 100 Most Iconic Technologies
abstract: “I just love imagining all of the angry emails we’re going to get from people who are like, ‘Why did you put the fulcrum on this list?’”
lead_paragraph: This week, we’re bringing you a Thanksgiving special that’s great for a long car ride, a day of cooking or avoiding conversation with your family. We’re counting down the 100 most iconic technologies of all time, starting with No. 100: Boats. Our definitive list was carefully crafted using an advanced methodology of vibes-only decision-making. By “iconic,” we mean technologies that have either changed the world, ruined it or at the very least made life a little more interesting. And because we love chaos, we’ll explain why we chose each one in roughly 30 seconds or less.
snippet: “I just love imagining all of the angry emails we’re going to get from people who are like, ‘Why did you put the fulcrum on this list?’”

headline: Notre-Dame Shines, and World Gets a Sneak Peek, on Macron’s Televised Tour
abstract: “You’ve achieved what was said to be impossible,” the French president told workers at the Paris monument, which will reopen after the 2019 fire.
lead_paragraph: The world got its first glimpse on Friday of the newly renovated Notre-Dame Cathedral in Paris.
snippet: “You’ve achieved what was said to be impossible,” the French president told workers at the Paris monument, which will reopen after the 2019 fire.

headline: Protests Erupt in Georgia as It Pulls Back From Pro-Western Path
abstract: Thousands of people took to the streets after the government said it had suspended talks on joining the European Union.
lead_paragraph: Thousands of people demonstrated in front of the Parliament building in the Georgian capital, Tbilisi, for a second day on Friday after the government announced that the country had suspended its bid to join the European Union for four years.
snippet: Thousands of people took to the streets after the government said it had suspended talks on joining the European Union.

headline: Britain’s Transport Secretary Quits After Phone Offense Revealed
abstract: In the latest setback for Prime Minister Keir Starmer, Louise Haigh resigned from the cabinet Friday after admitting she pleaded guilty to a type of fraud in 2014.
lead_paragraph: Prime Minister Keir Starmer of Britain suffered the first resignation from his cabinet on Friday when the transport secretary, Louise Haigh, quit hours after it emerged that she had been convicted of a fraud offense involving a phone a decade ago.
snippet: In the latest setback for Prime Minister Keir Starmer, Louise Haigh resigned from the cabinet Friday after admitting she pleaded guilty to a type of fraud in 2014.

headline: You’re Hungover. Can Exercise Help?
abstract: If you overdid it last night, here’s how to know whether it’s wise to sweat through it.
lead_paragraph: Electrolyte drinks, ibuprofen, a bagel overflowing with bacon, egg and cheese — everyone has their own way of nursing a hangover. There are also plenty of products that claim to make the experience less miserable, with little evidence to support them.
snippet: If you overdid it last night, here’s how to know whether it’s wise to sweat through it.

headline: The ‘Braiding Sweetgrass’ Author Wants Us to Give Thanks Every Day
abstract: The world is a gift, not a giant Amazon warehouse, Robin Wall Kimmerer said. In her new book, “The Serviceberry,” she proposes gratitude as an antidote to prevailing views of nature as a commodity.
lead_paragraph: Every summer, the botanist Robin Wall Kimmerer takes a group of students on a two-week field trip deep into the woods and bogs of the Adirondacks.
snippet: The world is a gift, not a giant Amazon warehouse, Robin Wall Kimmerer said. In her new book, “The Serviceberry,” she proposes gratitude as an antidote to prevailing views of nature as a commodity.

headline: World Gets First Glimpse Into Notre-Dame’s Renovated Interior
abstract: President Emmanuel Macron of France toured the Paris cathedral five years after it was damaged in a devastating fire. The landmark is expected to reopen to the public next month.
lead_paragraph: President Emmanuel Macron of France toured the Paris cathedral five years after it was damaged in a devastating fire. The landmark is expected to reopen to the public next month.
snippet: President Emmanuel Macron of France toured the Paris cathedral five years after it was damaged in a devastating fire. The landmark is expected to reopen to the public next month.

headline: British Lawmakers Vote to Legalize Assisted Dying in Landmark Decision
abstract: After an emotional debate, Parliament voted on Friday in favor of allowing assisted suicide for some terminally ill people in England and Wales.
lead_paragraph: After an emotive and at times impassioned debate, Britain’s lawmakers on Friday voted to allow assisted dying for terminally ill patients in England and Wales under strict conditions, opening the way to one of the most profound social changes in the country in decades.
snippet: After an emotional debate, Parliament voted on Friday in favor of allowing assisted suicide for some terminally ill people in England and Wales.

headline: Dr. Dave Weldon, Trump’s C.D.C. Pick, Was Not on Anyone’s Radar
abstract: But over the years, the former congressman’s views have often aligned with those of his potential boss, Robert F. Kennedy Jr. — particularly on vaccine safety.
lead_paragraph: Dr. Dave Weldon, a former Republican congressman who is President-elect Donald J. Trump’s pick to lead the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, has been off the political stage for more than 15 years.
snippet: But over the years, the former congressman’s views have often aligned with those of his potential boss, Robert F. Kennedy Jr. — particularly on vaccine safety.

headline: California Man to Reunite With Family 25 Years After He ‘Vanished With No Trace’
abstract: Marcella Nasseri saw a man who resembled her long-lost brother in the news. Fingerprint scans solved the decades-old case.
lead_paragraph: For years, Marcella Nasseri searched for the remains of her brother, who she believed had died after he mysteriously disappeared in Doyle, Calif., 25 years ago.
snippet: Marcella Nasseri saw a man who resembled her long-lost brother in the news. Fingerprint scans solved the decades-old case.

headline: Justice Dept. Girds for a Test of Its Independence
abstract: President-elect Donald Trump’s plans to install loyalists have left officials fearful that he intends to carry out his threats of retribution but hopeful that rule-of-law norms can hold.
lead_paragraph: It was an early case of Donald J. Trump seeking retribution through the Justice Department.
snippet: President-elect Donald Trump’s plans to install loyalists have left officials fearful that he intends to carry out his threats of retribution but hopeful that rule-of-law norms can hold.

headline: FIFA Should Pay Workers Injured Building the Qatar World Cup, Internal Report Says
abstract: An unpublished report on the soccer governing body’s responsibility for migrant workers recommends that it should compensate those harmed.
lead_paragraph: The soccer World Cup held in Qatar in 2022 took the most popular sporting event to the Middle East for the first time. But it was trailed for years by reports of injuries, and even deaths, suffered by workers who created an entirely new country — including a subway network, hotels and a nearly a dozen modern stadiums — in preparation for the tournament.
snippet: An unpublished report on the soccer governing body’s responsibility for migrant workers recommends that it should compensate those harmed.

headline: Syrian Rebels Breach City of Aleppo, in Biggest Advance in Years
abstract: A new assault on Syrian regime forces reached the major city, according to rebels and a war monitor. Government warplanes struck back at rebel territory.
lead_paragraph: Syrian rebels breached the major city of Aleppo on Friday, according to the fighters and a war monitor, reigniting the country’s long-running civil war with an intensity not seen in years.
snippet: A new assault on Syrian regime forces reached the major city, according to rebels and a war monitor. Government warplanes struck back at rebel territory.

headline: Five Action Movies to Stream Now
abstract: This month’s picks include a martial arts face-off, a hijacked plane and killer zombies.
lead_paragraph: Few films this year are as elegantly shot as Haofeng Xu and Junfeng Xu’s poetically violent martial arts street epic “100 Yards.” The Chinese film, set in 1920s Tianjin, begins with the sudden death of a martial arts master who leaves his academy to his ruthless apprentice, Qi Quan (Andy On), rather than his son, Shen An (Jacky Heung). A jilted An and a territorial Quan engage in a duel that escalates into a fight to the death for control of the academy and for the loyalty of the school’s gang of martial students.
snippet: This month’s picks include a martial arts face-off, a hijacked plane and killer zombies.

headline: Give Thanks for Leftovers
abstract: Turkey tikka masala, turkey tetrazzini, turkey pho, turkey congee, turkey à la king and, of course, the best Thanksgiving leftovers sandwich.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. How’d it go yesterday? Was the turkey moist? The gravy smooth? You enjoy the side dishes, the dinner rolls? Were the pies abundant? Did Cousin Amy keep her cool?
snippet: Turkey tikka masala, turkey tetrazzini, turkey pho, turkey congee, turkey à la king and, of course, the best Thanksgiving leftovers sandwich.

headline: What to Expect in a Second Trump Term
abstract: Readers worry that he will punish enemies and rule like an autocrat. Also: A redundant efficiency department; science and policy; emotional tears.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:
snippet: Readers worry that he will punish enemies and rule like an autocrat. Also: A redundant efficiency department; science and policy; emotional tears.

headline: Our Favorite Travel Destinations in 2024
abstract: From France’s Cap Ferret to Japan’s Kagoshima, T looks back at some of this year’s most enticing getaways.
snippet: From France’s Cap Ferret to Japan’s Kagoshima, T looks back at some of this year’s most enticing getaways.

headline: Review: This ‘Importance of Being Earnest’ Is a Fabulous Romp
abstract: A new production in London, starring Ncuti Gatwa, releases Oscar Wilde’s 1895 comedy from period convention and brings it stunningly into the 21st century.
lead_paragraph: Purists may reach for their smelling salts at the National Theater’s wild revival of “The Importance of Being Earnest,” the Oscar Wilde comedy concerned with self-identity, veiled sexuality and forming “an alliance,” as one character drolly puts it, “with a parcel.”
snippet: A new production in London, starring Ncuti Gatwa, releases Oscar Wilde’s 1895 comedy from period convention and brings it stunningly into the 21st century.

headline: No Corrections: Nov. 29, 2024
abstract: No corrections appeared in print on Friday, Nov. 29, 2024.
lead_paragraph: Errors are corrected during the press run whenever possible, so some errors noted here may not have appeared in all editions.
snippet: No corrections appeared in print on Friday, Nov. 29, 2024.

headline: Trump Disavowed Project 2025 During the Campaign. Not Anymore.
abstract: President-elect Donald J. Trump has filled his administration with people who have ties to the right-wing manifesto.
lead_paragraph: During the campaign, President-elect Donald J. Trump swore he had “nothing to do with” a right-wing policy blueprint known as Project 2025 that would overhaul the federal government, even though many of those involved in developing the plans were his allies.
snippet: President-elect Donald J. Trump has filled his administration with people who have ties to the right-wing manifesto.

headline: France Loses its Longtime Military Partner in Africa, Chad
abstract: The decision by Chad is another blow to what remained of France’s military influence in the troubled stretch of countries below the Sahara, where Russia’s influence has been growing.
lead_paragraph: France lost one of its staunchest military allies in the volatile Sahel region of Africa this week as Chad ended its longstanding defense partnership with the country, the latest blow to French efforts to maintain sway on the continent it once colonized.
snippet: The decision by Chad is another blow to what remained of France’s military influence in the troubled stretch of countries below the Sahara, where Russia’s influence has been growing.

headline: Stocks Resume Post-Election Rise
abstract: With Friday’s gains included, November was the best month in a year for the S&P 500.
lead_paragraph: Despite a furor set off by President-elect Donald J. Trump’s latest pronouncements about tariffs and immigration, the stock market resumed its upward surge in holiday-shortened trading on Friday, propelling the benchmark S&P 500 to its best monthly gain since November 2023.
snippet: With Friday’s gains included, November was the best month in a year for the S&P 500.

headline: Alice Hudson, Librarian Who Built a Trove of Historic Maps, Dies at 77
abstract: She transformed the New York Public Library’s collection of charts and atlases into one of the world’s largest and most accessible resources.
lead_paragraph: Alice Hudson, who, after enrolling in a mandatory geography course in college, took a detour from her plan to become a professional translator and went on to devote her career to building one of the world’s premier public map collections, died on Nov. 6 in Manhattan. She was 77.
snippet: She transformed the New York Public Library’s collection of charts and atlases into one of the world’s largest and most accessible resources.

headline: British Parliament Supports Assisted Dying
abstract: The bill applies to those who are at least 18 years old, have received a terminal diagnosis and have no more than six months to live. Two doctors and a judge would have to give their approval, and fatal drugs would need to be self-administered.
lead_paragraph: The bill applies to those who are at least 18 years old, have received a terminal diagnosis and have no more than six months to live. Two doctors and a judge would have to give their approval, and fatal drugs would need to be self-administered.
snippet: The bill applies to those who are at least 18 years old, have received a terminal diagnosis and have no more than six months to live. Two doctors and a judge would have to give their approval, and fatal drugs would need to be self-administered.

headline: Flashback: Your Weekly History Quiz, Nov. 30, 2024
abstract: Can you sort 8 historical events?
lead_paragraph: Can you sort 8 historical events?
snippet: Can you sort 8 historical events?

headline: Vito Is First Pug to Win National Dog Show
abstract: The pup became a sensation when he won best in show at the competition, which was broadcast on Thanksgiving Day. One judge said the 2-year-old is “everything a pug should be.”
lead_paragraph: As dozens of people applauded and cheered for him, Vito, a young pug, looked around, his four paws on the blue carpet. Did he know he had just won best in show at the National Dog Show?
snippet: The pup became a sensation when he won best in show at the competition, which was broadcast on Thanksgiving Day. One judge said the 2-year-old is “everything a pug should be.”

headline: Major Canadian News Outlets Sue OpenAI in New Copyright Case
abstract: A coalition of some of Canada’s biggest media companies is seeking billions of dollars in compensation for what they say is copyright infringement on their work through ChatGPT.
lead_paragraph: A coalition of Canada’s biggest news organizations is suing OpenAI, the maker of the artificial intelligence chatbot, ChatGPT, accusing the company of illegally using their content in the first case of its kind in the country.
snippet: A coalition of some of Canada’s biggest media companies is seeking billions of dollars in compensation for what they say is copyright infringement on their work through ChatGPT.

headline: Lake-Effect Storm Brings Heavy Snow to Great Lakes Region
abstract: Forecasters warned that some areas would be “paralyzed” by the storm. Nearly three feet of snow had already accumulated in Perrysburg, N.Y., about 30 miles south of Buffalo.
lead_paragraph: A lake-effect storm continued to blanket parts of the Great Lakes region with snow on Saturday, closing highways on one of the biggest travel weekends of the year and prompting Gov. Kathy Hochul of New York to declare a state of emergency on Friday in 11 counties.
snippet: Forecasters warned that some areas would be “paralyzed” by the storm. Nearly three feet of snow had already accumulated in Perrysburg, N.Y., about 30 miles south of Buffalo.

headline: Dozens Killed and Over 100 Missing in Nigeria After Boat Capsizes
abstract: Rescuers were searching for survivors after the vessel, taking passengers to a food market, capsized along the River Niger, officials said.
lead_paragraph: ABUJA, Nigeria — At least 27 people were killed and more than 100, mostly women, were missing on Friday after a boat transporting them to a food market capsized along the River Niger in northern Nigeria, the authorities said.
snippet: Rescuers were searching for survivors after the vessel, taking passengers to a food market, capsized along the River Niger, officials said.

headline: Shouldn’t Trump Voters Be Viewed as Traitors?
abstract: The magazine’s Ethicist columnist on whether voters should be held accountable for their chosen candidate’s behavior.
lead_paragraph: From my perspective, the attack on the Capitol spurred on by Donald Trump on Jan. 6, 2021, the efforts to nullify the results of the 2020 election with false electors and unfounded court cases and the persistent effort to discredit those election results without evidence amounted to an attempt to overthrow a pillar of our democracy. More to the point, 18 U.S. Code Chapter 115 includes crimes against the nation described as treason, misprision of treason, rebellion or insurrection, seditious conspiracy and advocating the overthrow of government. I hold anyone voting for Trump at least morally guilty for the consequences of Jan. 6 and everything that follows the recent election. Would you agree that people who vote for Trump in light of these circumstances are themselves guilty of treasonous acts? — Name Withheld
snippet: The magazine’s Ethicist columnist on whether voters should be held accountable for their chosen candidate’s behavior.

headline: Earl Holliman, Rugged, and Familiar, Screen Presence, Dies at 96
abstract: While never a big star, he was a recognizable one, with roles in “The Twilight Zone,” “Giant,” “Forbidden Planet” and the 1970s series “Police Woman.”
lead_paragraph: Earl Holliman, an iron-jawed actor who earned a star on Hollywood Boulevard for a prolific career that included a corral full of Westerns, an appearance on the first episode of “The Twilight Zone” and a turn as Angie Dickinson’s boss on the 1970s television drama “Police Woman,” died on Monday at his home in Studio City, Calif. He was 96.
snippet: While never a big star, he was a recognizable one, with roles in “The Twilight Zone,” “Giant,” “Forbidden Planet” and the 1970s series “Police Woman.”

headline: Syrian Rebels Reach Aleppo in Big Advance
abstract: Rebels reached the major city of Aleppo on Friday, according to the fighters and a war monitor, raising fears that Syria’s long-running civil war was reigniting with an intensity not seen in years.
lead_paragraph: Rebels reached the major city of Aleppo on Friday, according to the fighters and a war monitor, raising fears that Syria’s long-running civil war was reigniting with an intensity not seen in years.
snippet: Rebels reached the major city of Aleppo on Friday, according to the fighters and a war monitor, raising fears that Syria’s long-running civil war was reigniting with an intensity not seen in years.

headline: J. Stanley Pottinger, 84, Dies; Official Figured Out Identity of ‘Deep Throat’
abstract: A former Nixon official (and later a novelist), he led an investigation in which a shadowy Watergate figure squirmed when asked if he had been an anonymous whistle blower.
lead_paragraph: J. Stanley Pottinger, who as a high-ranking figure in the Department of Justice during the 1970s was probably the only person in government to figure out the identity of Deep Throat, the pseudonymous man who provided critical information to reporters in the Watergate scandal, died on Wednesday in Princeton, N.J. He was 84.
snippet: A former Nixon official (and later a novelist), he led an investigation in which a shadowy Watergate figure squirmed when asked if he had been an anonymous whistle blower.

headline: With Discounts on Offer, Shoppers Seem to Bite
abstract: Early data on online spending this week shows consumers are being drawn to discounts. A clearer picture of Black Friday sales, including in-store spending, will emerge in the days ahead.
lead_paragraph: For weeks, businesses have been sending consumers endless offers of discounts on all sorts of items. Finally, on this long weekend, it appears that consumers bit.
snippet: Early data on online spending this week shows consumers are being drawn to discounts. A clearer picture of Black Friday sales, including in-store spending, will emerge in the days ahead.

headline: The Evening: Holiday Shopping Got Off to a Cautious Start
abstract: Plus, a look inside a revived Notre Dame.
lead_paragraph: Shoppers headed into Black Friday weekend searching for deals and being choosier about their spending, retailers said, even as data suggested that consumer spending was still strong.
snippet: Plus, a look inside a revived Notre Dame.

headline: Trudeau Flies to Mar-a-Lago to See Trump Amid Tariff Concerns
abstract: Prime Minister Justin Trudeau of Canada is the first foreign G7 leader to visit President-elect Donald J. Trump since the election. He is under pressure to persuade Mr. Trump to back down from his tariff threat.
lead_paragraph: Prime Minister Justin Trudeau of Canada went to Florida on Friday night to see President-elect Donald J. Trump at Mar-a-Lago, two officials with direct knowledge of the visit said, after a threat by Mr. Trump to impose across-the-board tariffs on goods from Canada and Mexico on Day 1.
snippet: Prime Minister Justin Trudeau of Canada is the first foreign G7 leader to visit President-elect Donald J. Trump since the election. He is under pressure to persuade Mr. Trump to back down from his tariff threat.
